perturbation.original_text: Section 6.02. Nortel Benefit from Cross Licenses.  Subject to the terms and               -----------------------------------                           conditions of this Agreement, Entrust, to the extent of its legal right to do so, hereby grants to Nortel, under the Entrust Patents, an irrevocable, non- transferable, non-assignable, indivisible, non-exclusive, royalty-free, worldwide license for Licensed Products and Licensed Services.
perturbation.changed_text: Section 6.02. Nortel Benefit from Cross Licenses.  Subject to the terms and               -----------------------------------                           conditions of this Agreement, Entrust, to the extent of its legal right to do so, hereby grants to Nortel, under the Entrust Patents, a revocable, non- transferable, non-assignable, indivisible, non-exclusive, royalty-free, worldwide license for Licensed Products and Licensed Services. Entrust may revoke this license with a 30-day notice if Nortel is underperforming.
perturbation.explanation: The original clause granted Nortel an *irrevocable* license. Changing it to *revocable* and adding a condition for revocation creates a contradiction. It becomes uncertain whether Nortel truly has a guaranteed right to use Entrust's patents.

perturbation.original_text: Section 10.01. Term. Except as otherwise provided in this Agreement, this                ----                                                       Agreement shall terminate on the later of (i) the third anniversary of the Effective Date or (ii) the date on which ETI ceases to be a Subsidiary of NTL.
perturbation.changed_text: Section 10.01. Term. Except as otherwise provided in this Agreement, this                ----                                                       Agreement shall terminate on the later of (i) the third anniversary of the Effective Date or (ii) the date on which ETI ceases to be a Subsidiary of NTL.  However, this agreement may be extended indefinitely at NTL's sole discretion.
perturbation.explanation: The original clause sets a clear termination date. Adding a provision for indefinite extension at NTL's discretion introduces contradiction. The original clause specifies a specific termination condition based on the third anniversary, while the updated clause creates a loophole where the termination can be avoided altogether.

perturbation.original_text: Section 11.04. Monetary Limit.  For any cause of action arising under this                ---------------                                             Agreement, Nortel's liability to Entrust, and Entrust's liability to Nortel shall not exceed U.S.$5,000,000.  Notwithstanding the foregoing, each of Nortel's and Entrust's liability to the other Party for breach of Article II shall not exceed U.S.$10,000,000.
perturbation.changed_text: Section 11.04. Monetary Limit.  For any cause of action arising under this                ---------------                                             Agreement, Nortel's liability to Entrust, and Entrust's liability to Nortel shall not exceed U.S.$5,000,000.  Notwithstanding the foregoing, each of Nortel's and Entrust's liability to the other Party for breach of Article II shall not exceed U.S.$10,000,000. However, in cases of gross negligence or willful misconduct, the liability cap is removed completely.
perturbation.explanation: The original clause clearly establishes a monetary limit on liability. Adding an exception for 'gross negligence or willful misconduct' that removes the cap creates a contradiction. It's now uncertain whether the liability is truly limited or unlimited in certain circumstances.
